Award.AwardTitle: Conference Funding Proposal: Advances in Cryptology - CRYPTO 2012

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
CRYPTO is the Annual International Cryptology Conference, sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research), in cooperation with the Computer Science Department of the University of California, Santa Barbara. The first CRYPTO was held in 1981, and since then CRYPTO has been IACR's flagship conference, attracting researchers in the field of cryptology from all over the world.

The scope of research papers accepted to CRYPTO range from theoretical foundation of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes. This grant supports student attendance at CRYPTO. Students will have the opportunity to interact with many of the luminaries in the field during conference presentations, special tutorial sessions on hot topics, as well as in more informal settings including a reception and banquet dinners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CRYPTO is the Annual International Cryptology Conference, sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research). Since its establishment in 1981, CRYPTO has been the flagship conference in the field of cryptology.

At CRYPTO 2012, 48 papers were accepted for presentation. In addition, there were two invited talks and one tutorial session. Over 350 researchers from 30 countries attended the conference, among which about 100 were students. The large number of participants especially students has major impact on the development of the field.  

 

Proceedings of CRYPTO 2012 were published in Springer’s Lecture Notes in Computer Science and were made available at the conference, both in paper form and in electronic form. Abstracts and full versions of accepted papers were posted on the conference website. In addition, all presentations were professionally videotaped and made available online after the conference.

 

We provided stipends to 26 domestic student participants of CRYPTO 2012. Among the stipend recipients, nine were student authors and eight gave presentations at the conference. Also, eleven of the 26 stipend recipients were female students.

Students had the opportunities to present their papers, attend conference sessions, and interact with many of the luminaries in the field during various social events. Such opportunities will certainly help all the student participants in their training and professional development.

The conference website, with videotapted talks and  pointers to full versions of most papers, is at  http://www.iacr.org/conferences/crypto2012/
